H0.text: Fish births increase is how excess nitrogen from fertilizers negatively affects the Chesapeake Bay, because the nitrogen causes algae blooms that reduce dissolved oxygen in the water.

H1.text: Fish populations decrease when excess nitrogen from fertilizers drains into waterways that flow into the Chesapeake Bay, triggering algae blooms that reduce dissolved oxygen in the water.

H2.text: Sediment on the bottom of the Chesapeake Bay decreases when excess nitrogen fertilizers drain into its waterways, causing algae blooms that reduce dissolved oxygen.

H3.text: The rate of water runoff into the Chesapeake Bay increases because excess nitrogen fertilizers drain into the waterways feeding the bay, leading to algae blooms that reduce dissolved oxygen in the water.

A4.text: The pollution entering the bay has multiple components that contribute to algal blooms, principally the nutrients phosphorus and nitrogen.

A5.text: The algae prevents sunlight from reaching the bottom of the bay while alive and deoxygenates the bay's water when it dies and rots.
